history.content:
I've heard it's pretty low workload and somewhat interesting. EE 118 will definitely help you better understand ray tracing and how light actually physically behaves. It's a shame that a lot of graphics people don't understand the physics of what they're modeling and use these ridiculous fudged models just because it "looks right".

If you're going for graphics where physical accuracy is valued (ie CAD software and medical imaging) instead of quickly fudging things that look okay (ie game development), 118 would definitely help.

I've heard it's pretty low workload and somewhat interesting. EE 118 will definitely help you better understand ray tracing and how light actually physically behaves. It's a shame that a lot of graphics people don't understand the physics of what they're modeling and use these ridiculous fudged models just because it "looks right".

If you're going for graphics where physical accuracy is valued (ie CAD software and image processing) instead of quickly fudging things that look okay (ie game development), 118 would definitely help.

children.subject:
The physics classes are definitely a lot more theoretical. You would also need to take 110A (E&M) before taking 110B (optics). Wouldn't recommend unless you're super hardcore.

EE 117 (engineering E&M) is offered in the spring usually though, so maybe consider that one?
This is a bit far off, but how does it compare to the upper div physics optics/electromagnetism class? I dont think I would be able to take it right now, but I could consider taking it in the future.

history.content: As someone who is considering a path in computer graphics/vision, is EE118/218 important? I enjoy physics and have taken 7 series equivalent, but I have a tight schedule as I am in my last year. I am for sure going to take CS184 in the spring, so I was wondering if EE118 would have value for me. Is EE118/218 high workload? Also, what is the difference between the grad and undergrad versions? Thanks.
history.subject: EE218 and graphics
